signalslink:usageinfo-signalslink-text:
SignalsLink
Extends the Signals mod with additional components.

Block Sensor
Allows detecting the presence of a block at a selected neighboring position and, based on its type or the input signal, provides output information about its state or slot fill level, etc.
The Block Sensor identifies what block it is and outputs the corresponding signal.
Currently supported blocks are:
Anvil - if there is a sufficiently hot ingot on the anvil for forging, the output is signal 1. Otherwise it sends signal 0.
Doors, gates, trapdoors - For doors and gates you need to monitor the ground-level block on the hinge side. If the block is open, the output is signal 1; if it is closed, the output is signal 0.
Chest or, in general, a container or any blocks that have inventory slots (e.g. firepit, barrel, trough, etc.). The output signal depends on the input signal.
The input signal determines which slot should be scanned.
Signal 1-14 selects slots 0-13. The output is the slot fill level relative to the maximum stack capacity of the item in that slot, converted to a 0-15 signal.
Signal 15 means the sensor should detect the total fill level of all slots, e.g. an entire chest.
Some other block not listed above - If there is nothing in the monitored space (air), the output is signal 0. If there is water, the output is 2 for fresh water or 3 for salt water. If there is any other block, the output is signal 1.

Entity sensor
Detects the presence of entities (players, animals, wild animals, or monsters) in a marked area and can provide information on its outputs about their count, type, or state. The sensor requires a charge to operate using one or more temporal gears (Temporal gears). The consumption rate then depends on the size of the monitored area.
Inputs x, y, z determine the size of the monitored area in blocks.
On the Error output there is signal 1 if the sensor is discharged, otherwise 0.
The Output 1 configuration and Output 2 configuration inputs determine what information will be provided on outputs 1 and 2. You can get different information on each output depending on these input settings.
Options are:
1 - Output returns Count. The number of detected entities.
2 - Output returns Category. Bit flags of entity category 0–3: player, creature, animal, wild animal.
3 - Output returns Life state. All detected entities are: 1–dead, 2–alive, or 15–mixed.
4 - Output returns Sex. All detected entities are: 1–male, 2–female, or 15–mixed.
5 - Output returns Age. All detected entities are: 1–young, 2–adult, or 15–mixed.
6 - Output returns Species. All detected entities are: 1–player, 2–animal, 3–wild animal, 4–creature, or 15–mixed.
7 - Output returns Reproductive state. All detected entities are: 1–ready to mate, 2–pregnant, 3–nursing, or 15–mixed.
8 - Output returns Reproductive state flags. Bit flags 0–2: ready to mate, pregnant, nursing.
9 - Output returns Minimum generation. The minimum detected generation is: 0–15. Present entities without a specified generation are ignored.
10 - Output returns Maximum generation. The maximum detected generation is: 0–15. Present entities without a specified generation are ignored.
11 - Output returns Minimum weight. The minimum detected weight is: 1–starving, 2–low, 3–decent, 4–good. Present entities without specified weight (not animals) are ignored.
12 - Output returns Maximum weight. The maximum detected weight is: 1–starving, 2–low, 3–decent, 4–good. Present entities without specified weight (not animals) are ignored.
